title: Trump, China and an Unhappy Birthday
summary: Let's hope the President gets something in return for pretending Xi Jinping is a good guy.. President Donald Trump is rarely criticized for being too nice on Twitter. But who can support his oddly cheerful conduct of foreign social-media relations on Tuesday morning? Mr. Trump wished a happy birthday to China's communist government, currently celebrating seven decades of suppressing liberty. Americans must hope this is merely the start of the deal on trade and not a policy statement on freedom in Asia.

title: Dallas Officer Found Guilty in Shooting of Black Neighbor
summary: Former police officer Amber Guyger faces up to 99 years in prison for murder of Botham Jean. DALLAS-A jury on Tuesday found a former Dallas police officer guilty of murder​for shooting and killing her upstairs neighbor after she mistakenly walked into the wrong apartment.

title: Foreign Influence and Double Standards
summary: Democrats want to stop Barr from investigating what happened in 2016.. Washington is in an impeachment frenzy, which is a dangerous moment for facts and context. title: There Is a Commission-Free Lunch
summary: Competition drives stock trading fees to zero without a federal rule.. Charles Schwab caused brokerage stocks to tumble on Tuesday by announcing commission-free online trades that could trigger a cascade across the industry. Behold how competitive markets are making investing less expensive for ordinary folks without government intervention.

title: Slowing Trade Hits Global Manufacturing
summary: U.S. factory activity contracts for second straight month; WTO warns that slowing world trade could hit investment and jobs. title: Juul Hires Another Top Altria Executive
summary: Altria's head of regulatory affairs to take over similar role at e-cigarette startup. Juul Labs Inc. is bringing over a second high-ranking executive from Marlboro maker Altria Group Inc. as the vaping startup attempts to repair its damaged relationship with regulators amid a rise in teen vaping.

title: Ringmaster Rashida Tlaib Introduces the Impeachment Circus
summary: Big fun under the big top as Democrats walk a tightrope. But will there be enough elephants?. President Trump had to know this was coming. "We're gonna go in there and we're gonna impeach the motherf-." She wasn't bluffing.

title: All Roads Lead to Mueller
summary: The Russia collusion morass threatens to spoil the Democrats' impeachment drama.. Watergate comparisons are in the air but a big difference is overlooked. title: Electricity Doesn't Light Up the Soul
summary: Secular humanism was full of promise. Now it's having an existential crisis.. The 20th-century left tended to define progress in terms of material goods, and that was true of liberals and Communists alike. Lyndon B. Johnson waged "war on poverty," and in 1920 Lenin confidently declared that "communism is Soviet government plus the electrification of the whole country."

title: Impeachment Isn't Futile for the Left
summary: They want Trump out, but taking control of the party is more important.. Why are Democrats pressing impeachment when the possibility of getting 20 Republican Senate votes to convict President Trump is so remote? Impeachment is the left's means of gaining control of the Democratic Party-which is liberal, but not as far left as many Republicans imagine.

title: Schwab Cuts Fees on Online Stock Trades to Zero, Rattling Rivals
summary: The move by Schwab, the largest e-broker, shook up the sector as it grapples with investor expectations of low or no-fee financial services. title: To Make Banks Stable, End, Don't Mend, the Repo Market
summary: Simplifying how financial institutions borrow would make the system more resilient.. 'I don't understand how your 'repo' market works," a veteran Scandinavian banker tells me. "There's nothing like it at home; our world is much simpler."

title: Test-Site Administrator to Plead Guilty in College Admissions Case
summary: Prosecutors recommend at least two years in prison for Igor Dvorskiy, who allegedly took bribes in exchange for allowing SAT, ACT cheating. Igor Dvorskiy, a West Hollywood, Calif., high school administrator who prosecutors say took bribes to allow a test proctor to cheat on SAT and ACT exams, has agreed to plead guilty in connection to his role in the sprawling college-admissions cheating scheme, according to a plea agreement filed with the court.

title: 'A Guest of the Reich' Review: The Honored Prisoner
summary: Gertrude Legendre, an American socialite with a taste for adventure, was for six months held captive by the Nazis.. In September 1944, while at the Ritz in Paris celebrating the city's liberation, Gertrude Legendre made the reckless decision to visit the front. She loved adventure and wanted to get close enough "to smell the fighting." Together with three American intelligence officers, she set off for the German border village of Wallendorf, which they thought had been taken by the Allies. The idea was to "mosey up to the line," as one of her companions put it, "so the lady could hear some gunfire." When they arrived, they heard plenty of shots, but the shots were directed at them. The village had been retaken by the Nazis.

title: Polls Argue Against Impeachment
summary: Nixon only fell after Republicans defected. So far, Trump retains their strong support.. When Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. was a Harvard undergraduate, he wrote an essay criticizing Plato as "loose and unscientific" and sent it to his intellectual hero, Ralph Waldo Emerson, who promptly set him straight. "I have read your piece," Emerson replied. "When you strike at a king, you must kill him."

title: JetBlue to Take Customer-Service Tech to the Skies

title: Watchdog Faults DEA Response to Opioid Deaths
summary: Justice Department's inspector general says drug agency didn't work to rein in production. The U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration was slow to respond to the nation's opioid crisis, the Justice Department's watchdog said in a report that criticized the agency for allowing drug manufacturers to significantly increase the production of powerful painkillers as overdose-death rates soared.

title: GE to Pay $2.7 Million Over Cuba Sanctions

title: Justice Department Given Until Nov. 15 to Decide on Andrew McCabe

title: How to Take Part in Italy's Grape Harvest
summary: More wine-loving visitors to Italy are joining in the harvest. Here's where to lend a hand-and a foot. title: Is a Carbon Tax the Least Bad Green Plan?
summary: The market-based carbon-tax proposal by the Climate Leadership Council may be one of the last chances for American conservatives to have a voice in the crafting of legislation fighting climate change.. Christopher Crane and Ted Halstead tout the Climate Leadership Council's (CLC) proposed carbon-emissions tax combined with a carbon dividend paid to American families as a pro-business, pro-environment and pro-consumer climate solution ("How to Cut Emissions Without Wrecking the Economy," op-ed, Sept. 23). They say that a carbon "fee" will start at $40 a ton and increase annually at 5% above inflation. Assuming 2% inflation, the $40 fee will be $110 (an increase of 175%) in 15 years. That type of financial bite will accomplish a desired change in American lifestyles, but also might depress business and consumer sentiment, disrupt vital economic sectors and dampen economic growth. "Dividends" (i.e., rebated tax money) will offset the pain, but in Washington the house always wins.

title: No End in Sight for California Homeless Mess
summary: Mental illness, addiction and the release of thousands of prisoners, all undoubtedly contribute to the current California homeless situation, but the core of the problem is supply and demand.. title: Why a Baseball Sweater From 1903 Is Surprisingly On Trend Today
summary: Around the turn of the 20th century, professional baseball players wore chunky turtleneck sweaters that look surprisingly au courant today. I pity those shivering relief pitchers and resting batters in New York City and St. Louis, all bundled up in hoodies and fleece zip-ups, biding their time. But, as John Thorn, the official historian for Major League Baseball, explained, professional baseball seasons have always been this long. Amateur seasons in the 1850s and '60s could even go longer, extending past Thanksgiving. Layering outerwear over one's uniform is hardly a new solution.

title: New York Fed Adds About $54.9 Billion to Financial System
summary: Latest transaction seeks to relieve funding pressure in money markets. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York added $54.85 billion to the financial system Tuesday by using the market for repurchase agreements, or repo, to relieve funding pressure in money markets.

title: Stocks to Watch: Facebook, Apple, McCormick and U.S. Steel
summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively Tuesday. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Tuesday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: A Wild Ride
summary: Photos of Iger over the years from his new book, The Ride of a Lifetime. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: How to Succeed in Baseball Without Spending Money
summary: The Tampa Bay Rays opened the year with a budget of about $60 million, the lowest in the major leagues. They still finished with 96 wins and earned a spot in the postseason.. Money still doesn't ensure success in baseball. The Boston Red Sox and Chicago Cubs, the organizations with the biggest payrolls in their respective leagues, both missed the 2019 playoffs despite combining to allocate about $450 million on players. The Oakland Athletics, the model for winning with limited financial resources, will participate in October for the 10th time this century.

title: The Japanese Stock Market Is Cheap if You're Cheerful
summary: Abenomics isn't such a dud as many investors seem to think and Japan's stocks merit watching if the global economy turns up. Profits are up. Deflation is over. Yet Japan's stock market is widely reviled, valued even more cheaply than the struggling eurozone.

title: China Marks 70 Years of Communist Rule as Hong Kong Boils Over
summary: President Xi oversees tightly choreographed showcase of nationalistic iconography and military firepower. BEIJING-Chinese President Xi Jinping presided over a grandiose military parade marking the 70th anniversary of Communist rule, a projection of strength as the country wrestles with a challenge from President Trump, while Hong Kong braced for another round of anti-Beijing protests.

title: Many Black Voters Like Biden, but Some Are Open to Other Democrats
summary: Former vice president enjoys wide, but perhaps soft, African-American support in early primary states. Kim Solomon was surprised to see Democratic presidential candidate Kamala Harris seated in the first row of pews at Royal Missionary Baptist Church in the predominantly African-American city of North Charleston, S.C.

title: Amazon's Grocery-Store Plan Advances With Los Angeles Leases
summary: Stores are also expected in Chicago and Philadelphia. Amazon.com Inc. is advancing a plan to open a chain of U.S. grocery stores with early outposts in Los Angeles, Chicago and Philadelphia, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Japan Airlines' New Seating Policy Isn't Child's Play
summary: Children under the age of two will be flagged in the company's online booking system. Japan Airlines isn't kidding around.

title: GM Strike, Now in Its Third Week, Wears on Both Sides
summary: Month's end brings bills and missed paychecks for workers; GM feels financial strains of lost factory production. The United Auto Workers strike at General Motors Co. is in its third week with workers on the picket lines fighting fatigue and the company feeling the financial strains of lost factory production.

title: CMOs Expect Bigger Marketing Budgets, Despite Economic Concerns
summary: Political uncertainty and red flags on the economy don't weigh on CMOs, study finds. Recession fears are rising and companies are scrutinizing their spending, but top marketers still think they'll get more money to spend next year, a new Gartner Inc. survey says.

title: Japan's New Tax Increase Tests Economy's Strength
summary: The first sales-tax increase in more than five years threatens to dissuade skittish consumers. TOKYO-Japan raised its national sales tax for the first time in more than five years on Tuesday, putting the world's third-largest economy and its cautious consumers to the test.

title: A Gamble to Reshape the Global Airline Industry
summary: Delta will pay a steep premium for a 20% share of Latam as part of a bold plan to better integrate far-flung markets. Do airlines actually benefit from global alliances like SkyTeam and Oneworld? Delta just bet $2.3 billion they don't.

title: Why Whales Are Worrying Lobstermen in Maine
summary: Resume Subscription. Along the rocky coast of Maine, lobstermen are worried new federal requirements to clear fishing lines from the path of endangered whales will damage their iconic New England industry.

title: Popular in Wisconsin: Cheese, the Packers and...Risky Bonds
summary: State agency facilitated some municipal-market deals now going sour. Wisconsin has long been famous for its lakes and cheese. Now it is becoming known for risky debt.

title: Teen Hackers Try to Convince Parents They Are Up to Good
summary: High-school students are forming hacking clubs to solve problems through coding. The first rule of Hack Club is: You talk about Hack Club. The second rule of Hack Club is: You talk about Hack Club.

title: Ready, Set, Algorithms! Teams Learn AI by Racing Cars
summary: Morningstar, Liberty Mutual workers are coming up with business ideas after exploring machine learning via mini self-driving vehicles. Employees at companies including Morningstar Inc. and Liberty Mutual Group Inc. are learning about advanced artificial-intelligence techniques by programming and racing miniature self-driving cars.

title: Fed's Evans: U.S. Still on Path for 'Solid' 2.25% GDP This Year
summary: Chicago Fed president says 'most concerns over growth are about potential risks'. Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago President Charles Evans said Tuesday that Fed rate cuts were necessary to keep the economy on its current path, which remains generally healthy despite some key risks.

title: Crypto Startup to Pay $24 Million in SEC Settlement
summary: Initial coin offering that raised billions of dollars allegedly violated investor-protection laws. A startup behind one of the largest initial coin offerings of the past several years will pay $24 million to resolve a U.S. regulator's allegations that its deal violated federal investor-protection laws.

title: Nike-Backed Running Coach Salazar Hit With Doping Ban
summary: Endocrinologist Jeffrey S. Brown also receives a four-year suspension. Alberto Salazar, the Nike -backed distance-running coach who led British runner Mo Farah and American Galen Rupp to Olympic medals, received a four-year ban for orchestrating and facilitating prohibited doping conduct Monday following an investigation by the U.S. Anti-Doping Agency.

title: Peru's President Dissolves Congress, Accusing Lawmakers of Blocking Reforms
summary: Lawmakers respond by suspending president's powers and swearing in his vice president as new president. LIMA, Peru-Peru's President Martín Vizcarra announced on Monday that he was dissolving Congress, prompting lawmakers to suspend his powers and swear in the country's vice president as the new president, and setting up a constitutional crisis and possible political unrest in one of Washington's closest Latin American allies.

title: UPS Gets FAA Nod for Widespread Drone Deliveries
summary: Federal approval marks another important gain for champions of commercial unmanned aircraft. United Parcel Service Inc. said it received the first-of-its-kind federal approval to start setting up a fleet of unmanned aircraft to deliver health supplies and eventually consumer packages potentially throughout the U.S.

title: U.S. Alleges California Tour Guide Spied for Chinese Intelligence
summary: Dead drops, double agent and piles of cash involved in the scheme, according to complaint. SAN FRANCISCO-A tour guide for Chinese visitors to California was also secretly working for Chinese intelligence, U.S. authorities alleged Monday as they unsealed a criminal complaint involving a double agent, dead drops and bundles of cash.

title: U.S. to Join Trump Lawsuit Seeking to Block Disclosure of Tax Returns
summary: The U.S. is set to file a submission in the case by Wednesday. NEW YORK-The U.S. attorney's office in Manhattan said Monday that the U.S. would participate in a lawsuit filed by President Trump that seeks to block a subpoena for eight years of his tax returns.

title: Consultant Linked to Surveillance of Former Credit Suisse Executive Reported Dead
summary: Unidentified consultant who connected bank with private investigators is said to have died by suicide. A consultant who helped Credit Suisse Group AG hire investigators to trail the bank's former wealth-management chief died in an apparent suicide last week, a lawyer in Switzerland said Monday night.

title: Pompeo Took Part in Ukraine Call, Official Says
summary: Secretary of State listened in on July 25 Trump-Zelensky contact that is center of impeachment inquiry. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo was among the administration officials who listened in on the July 25 phone call between President Trump and Ukraine's president, a senior State Department official said Monday, a disclosure that ties the State Department more closely to the House impeachment inquiry.

title: Midwest's Faltering Economies Will Spread Pain Nationwide
summary: Financial strain is increasing for farmers and manufacturers in the heartland. With the fortunes of flashy young companies such as We Co. and Peloton stealing headlines, it may be easy to forget about the worsening economic condition of flyover country, USA. That would be a mistake.

title: Aramco Plans to Pay $75 Billion Yearly Dividend
summary: Saudi oil giant intends to make payouts for the next five years as it continues to lay the groundwork for an IPO. Saudi Arabian Oil Co. is targeting potential nongovernment investors with plans to pay out a total annual dividend of $75 billion as it builds toward an initial public offering expected this year.
